Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Help.Tip: Output all specified image traces?
Help.Text:
ktmig - ALL_OUT
Output all specified image traces?
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES  (Output all specified image traces.)
 Allowed = NO   (Output only image traces corresponding to input traces.)
 If ALL_OUT=YES, the output will be all the image traces specified by the
 output grid parameters including those that do not correspond to input
 traces.
 
 Output of image traces may be further restricted if the SPARSE option is
 turned on.
 
 ALL_OUT should be set to YES when generating broadcast patterns.

Help.Tip: Should KTMIG produce a single image regardless of input offset?
Help.Text:
ktmig - ONE_IMAGE
Should KTMIG produce a single image regardless of input offset?
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO
 Allowed = YES
 If ONE_IMAGE = YES, then a single image is produced regardless of input
 offsets.  Header word 6 for output traces is set to the center value of the
 offset bin associated with the offset of the first input trace.  The imaging
 aperture is determined by this same offset bin.
 
 If ONE_IMAGE = NO, then a separate image is created for each offset bin
 occupied by an input trace.  In this case a new image is created each time an
 input trace occupies a different offset bin.

Help.Tip: Type of sum reduce at output.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_SUM_REDUCE
Type of sum reduce at output.
 
 Default = GLOBAL
 Allowed = LOCAL

Help.Tip: Define image groups by header word HDR_GROUP.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_GROUP
Define image groups by header word HDR_GROUP.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO  KMIG will not define groups by header word HDR_GROUP.
 Allowed = YES KMIG will     define groups by header word HDR_GROUP.

Help.Tip: Header word to define groups.
Help.Text:
ktmig - HDR_GROUP
Header word to define groups.
 
 Default = 55
 Allowed = 1-64 KMIG will define groups by header word HDR_GROUP.

Help.Tip: Choice of output type desired.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_OUTPUT
Choice of output type desired.
 
 Default = IMAGE
 Allowed = IMAGE  (Production output of the normal migration image.)
 Allowed = VEL    (Diagnostic output of the migration velocity field.)
 Allowed = TIME   (Diagnostic output of the two-way travel time.)
 Allowed = AA     (Diagnostic output of the anti-aliasing coefficients.)
 Allowed = AMPL   (Diagnostic output of the migration amplitude.)

Help.Tip: Whether to use a 3D, 2D or multiple 2D algorithm.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DIMENSION
Whether to use a 3D, 2D or multiple 2D algorithm.
 
 Default = 3D
 Allowed = 2D
 Allowed = MULT_2D
 Allowed = 3D
 If DIMENSION = 3D, then a 3D algorithm is used and both "X" parameters and
 "Y" parameters are active.  The migration velocity file must be 3D.
 
 If DIMENSION = 2D, then a 2D algorithm is used, all "X" parameters pertain to
 the inline direction, all "Y" parameters are ignored and the aperture has
 extent in the inline direction only.  Only one 2D line can be migrated in
 each job.  The migration velocity file may be 2D or 3D.
 
 If DIMENSION = MULT_2D, then a 2D algorithm is used, all "X" parameters
 pertain to the inline direction and the aperture has extent in the inline
 direction only.  HOWEVER the "Y" parameters must be set appropriately for
 the HDR_Y values in the separate 2D lines.  Several 2D lines can be migrated
 in one job.  The migration velocity file must be 3D.

Help.Tip: Interpolate input to DT_INTERP sample interval before imaging.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DT_INTERP
Interpolate input to DT_INTERP sample interval before imaging.
 
 Default = 0.001
 Allowed = DT >= real > 0.0
 Interpolate input traces to DT_INTERP sample interval, in seconds, before
 imaging.  DT_INTERP must divide input DT evenly.
 
 Input trace samples are interpolated (if necessary) to a sample interval of
 DT_INTERP seconds prior to imaging to insure adequate temporal resolution
 of the output image.  Normally 0.001 or 0.002 seconds is adequate.

Help.Tip: Remove the image files when the job is completed.
Help.Text:
ktmig - REMOVE_IMAGE
Remove the image files when the job is completed.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES (KTMIG will remove the image files at the end of the job.)
 Allowed = NO  (KTMIG will not remove the image files at the end of the job.)

Help.Tip: Perform forward (migration) or inverse (modeling) operation.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_DIR
Perform forward (migration) or inverse (modeling) operation.
 
 Default = FORWARD
 Allowed = FORWARD  (Perform time migration.)
 Allowed = INVERSE  (Perform modeling or inverse time migration.)

Help.Tip: Azimuth angle, in degrees, for inverse time migration.
Help.Text:
ktmig - AZIMUTH
Azimuth angle, in degrees, for inverse time migration.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real
 Azimuth is measured in degrees clockwise from north looking down to the
 direction from source to receiver (compass angle).  Source and receiver
 locations in the modeled data will be determined by AZIMUTH and offset.

Help.Tip: Root name of image file names.
Help.Text:
ktmig - ROOT_IMAGE
Root name of image file names.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 KTMIG places image traces for each CPU in a separate temporary disk file.
 If ROOT_IMAGE is other than NONE, KTMIG will construct the image files
 using the pathname prefix ROOT_IMAGE.
 
 If ROOT_IMAGE = NONE, KTMIG will construct the image files using a default.

Help.Tip: Stack the output traces.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_STACK
Stack the output traces.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO
 If OPT_STACK=YES  KMIG will     stack the output traces from all pes.
 If OPT_STACK=NO   KMIG will not stack the output traces from all pes.
 If OPT_STACK=NO and OPT_TROT=LAST
 KMIG will write the image traces from each pe to a separate FILE
 whose name will be defined by ROOT_TROT with the pe index and '.trc' apended.
 KMIG will also write a list of those file names and the number of
 traces written to the file to an ascii file.
 whose name will be defined by ROOT_TROT with '.list' apended.

Help.Tip: Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_TROT
Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES
 Allowed = NO
 Allowed = LAST
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_image_trot stating the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
Help.Text:
ktmig - NUM_TROT
Write output to trot file every NUM_TROT traces.
 
 Default = 999999
 Allowed = INT>0
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_image_trot stating the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Select file name.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SELECT_ROOT_TROT
Select file name.
 
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_image_trot stating the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Output file name.
Help.Text:
ktmig - ROOT_TROT
Output file name.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = character
 If OPT_TROT=YES  KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces.
 If OPT_TROT=NO   KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 If OPT_TROT=LAST KMIG will write the current image to file ROOT_TROT
 every NUM_TROT input traces and after the last input trace.
 KMIG will print a banner starting with kmig_image_trot stating the number
 of input traces contained in the image at output time.
 Header word HDR_FOLD is set to the number of input traces in the image.

Help.Tip: Header word for the x-coordinate of the output image volume.
Help.Text:
ktmig - HDR_X
Header word for the x-coordinate of the output image volume.
 
 Default = 7
 Allowed = 7, 8, 17, 18
 Allowed values for HDR_X and HDR_Y respectively are (7, 8); (8, 7); (17, 18);
 and (18, 17).  No other combinations are permitted.

Help.Tip: Header word for the y-coordinate of the output image volume.
Help.Text:
ktmig - HDR_Y
Header word for the y-coordinate of the output image volume.
 
 Default = 8
 Allowed = 7, 8, 17, 18
 Allowed values for HDR_X and HDR_Y respectively are (7, 8); (8, 7); (17, 18);
 and (18, 17).  No other combinations are permitted.

Help.Tip: Sort order of input and output data.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SORT_ORDER
Sort order of input and output data.
 
 Default = X_IS_FAST
 Allowed = X_IS_FAST
 Allowed = Y_IS_FAST
 If SORT_ORDER = X_IS_FAST, then HDR_X is the more rapidly changing header
 word and HDR_Y is the more slowly changing header word for both input and
 output.
 
 If SORT_ORDER = Y_IS_FAST, then HDR_Y is the more rapidly changing header
 word and HDR_X is the more slowly changing header word for both input and
 output.

Help.Tip: First value of HDR_X in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
ktmig - X_INIT
First value of HDR_X in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: First value of HDR_Y in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
ktmig - Y_INIT
First value of HDR_Y in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Time of the first sample in the output image traces, in seconds.
Help.Text:
ktmig - TIM_INIT
Time of the first sample in the output image traces, in seconds.
 
 Default = TSTRT
 Allowed = real

Help.Tip: Value at the center of the first offset bin, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OFF_INIT
Value at the center of the first offset bin, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 KTMIG uses header word 6 to determine an input trace's offset.

Help.Tip: Increment between HDR_X values in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
ktmig - X_INC
Increment between HDR_X values in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Increment between HDR_Y values in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
ktmig - Y_INC
Increment between HDR_Y values in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Time sample interval, in seconds, in the output image traces.
Help.Text:
ktmig - TIM_INC
Time sample interval, in seconds, in the output image traces.
 
 Default = DT
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Increment of offset values between offset bins.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OFF_INC
Increment of offset values between offset bins.
 
 Default = 200
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Increment of offset values between offset bins, in feet or meters.  OFF_INC is
 also equal to the width of an offset bin.

Help.Tip: Last value of HDR_X in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
ktmig - X_LAST
Last value of HDR_X in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 100
 Allowed = real >= X_INIT

Help.Tip: Last value of HDR_Y in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
ktmig - Y_LAST
Last value of HDR_Y in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 100
 Allowed = real >= Y_INIT

Help.Tip: Time of the last sample in the output image traces, in seconds.
Help.Text:
ktmig - TIM_LAST
Time of the last sample in the output image traces, in seconds.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real >= TIM_INIT

Help.Tip: Value at the center of the last offset bin, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OFF_LAST
Value at the center of the last offset bin, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real >= OFF_INIT

Help.Tip: Total number of HDR_X values in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
ktmig - X_TOT
Total number of HDR_X values in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 101
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Total number of HDR_Y values in the output image volume.
Help.Text:
ktmig - Y_TOT
Total number of HDR_Y values in the output image volume.
 
 Default = 101
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Total number of samples in the output image traces.
Help.Text:
ktmig - TIM_TOT
Total number of samples in the output image traces.
 
 Default = NDPT
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Total number of offset bins.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OFF_TOT
Total number of offset bins.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Variable depth step option.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_STEP
Variable depth step option.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = CONSTANT - use a constant depth step size of DEP_INC
 Allowed = VARIABLE - use defined arrays of step size - depth - frequency

Help.Tip: What method for interpolating output traces.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_OUT_INT
What method for interpolating output traces.
 
 Default = LINEAR
 Allowed = LINEAR   (Use linear   interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = LAGRANGE (Use lagrange interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = NEAREST  (Use nearest  interpolation for output traces. )
 Allowed = NONE     (Use no       interpolation for output traces. )

Help.Tip: Half length of output trace interpolation operator.
Help.Text:
ktmig - LEN_OUT_INT
Half length of output trace interpolation operator.
 
 Default = 10
 Allowed = int>0
 When OPT_OUT_INT=LAGRANGE the output trace is interpolation from the
 image trace using a lagrange operator whose length to either side is
 LEN_OUT_INT * output time or depth samples

Help.Tip: Depth values for variable depth increment.
Help.Text:
ktmig - STEP_TIM
Depth values for variable depth increment.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Depth increment values at step_tim.
Help.Text:
ktmig - STEP_TIM_INC
Depth increment values at step_tim.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real (array)

Help.Tip: Whether to use sparse output.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_SPARSE
Whether to use sparse output.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO      (Do not use sparse output.)
 Allowed = YES     (Use sparse output.)

Help.Tip: First value of HDR_X in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SP_X_INIT
First value of HDR_X in the sparse output.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real (array)
 SP_X parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Increment between HDR_X values in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SP_X_INC
Increment between HDR_X values in the sparse output.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0 (array)
 SP_X parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Last value of HDR_X in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SP_X_LAST
Last value of HDR_X in the sparse output.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real >= SP_X_INIT (array)
 SP_X parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Total number of HDR_X values in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SP_X_TOT
Total number of HDR_X values in the sparse output.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int > 0 (array)
 SP_X parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: First value of HDR_Y in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SP_Y_INIT
First value of HDR_Y in the sparse output.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real (array)
 SP_Y parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Increment between HDR_Y values in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SP_Y_INC
Increment between HDR_Y values in the sparse output.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0 (array)
 SP_Y parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Last value of HDR_Y in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SP_Y_LAST
Last value of HDR_Y in the sparse output.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real >= SP_Y_INIT (array)
 SP_Y parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Total number of HDR_Y values in the sparse output.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SP_Y_TOT
Total number of HDR_Y values in the sparse output.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int > 0 (array)
 SP_Y parameters are linked arrays with each row defining additional output.

Help.Tip: Units to use for aperture parameter values.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_AP_UNITS
Units to use for aperture parameter values.
 
 Default = GRID
 Allowed = DIST  (Use feet or meters.)
 Allowed = GRID  (Use grid units (header word 7 and 8 units).)
 Allowed = ANG   (Use angle in degrees.)
 The value of OPT_AP_UNITS determines which arrays of the aperture parameters
 linked arrays are active.

Help.Tip: Time increment for the travel time map, in seconds.
Help.Text:
ktmig - AP_TIM_INC
Time increment for the travel time map, in seconds.
 
 Default = Use 10 * TIM_INC
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 The travel time map from input trace to output trace is computed on a coarse
 time grid with an increment of AP_TIM_INC seconds.  The coarse time map is
 linearly interpolated to form the applied time map.
 
 Increasing TIME_TAB may reduce memory and decrease CPU time at the expense of
 reduced mapping accuracy.

Help.Tip: Constant velocity used only for aperture angle calculations.
Help.Text:
ktmig - CONST_VEL_ANG
Constant velocity used only for aperture angle calculations.
 
 Default = 2000.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 Calculations that relate aperture in distance or grid units to aperture in
 angle require an approximate depth conversion.  The CONST_VEL_ANG value is
 used only for that depth conversion.  Aperture values expressed in angle are
 approximate.
 
 If CONST_VEL_ANG = 0.0, then do not use aperture expressed in angle.

Help.Tip: Maximum half-aperture in the x direction, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DIST_AP_X_MAX
Maximum half-aperture in the x direction, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 100.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Maximum half-aperture in y direction, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DIST_AP_Y_MAX
Maximum half-aperture in y direction, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = 100.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0

Help.Tip: Spacing within aperture and travel time table.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DIST_AP_X_INC
Spacing within aperture and travel time table.
 
 Default = -1 = 5. * X_INC
 Allowed = real
 For depth imaging this defines the maximum size of travel time tables.
 Increasing this increases memory linearly and CPU nonlinearly.
 The travel time table is computed and saved using a spacing of DIST_AP_X_INC
 between locations within the table. The larger DIST_AP_X_INC gets the less CPU
 time and memory is recquired at the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Y spacing within precomputed tables.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DIST_AP_Y_INC
Y spacing within precomputed tables.
 
 Default = -1 = 5 * Y_INC
 Allowed = real
 kdmig precomputes a number of tables on a coarse horizontal grid.
 DIST_AP_Y_INC defines the Y spacing within these tables.
 Needed values are computed from these tables via linear interpolation.
 Decreasing DIST_AP_Y_INC increases memory linearly and CPU nonlinearly.
 
 For depth migration:
 The travel time table is computed and saved using a spacing of AP_Y_INC
 between locations within the table. The larger AP_Y_INC gets the less CPU
 time and memory is recquired at the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Maximum half-aperture in the x direction, in grid units.
Help.Text:
ktmig - GRID_AP_X_MAX
Maximum half-aperture in the x direction, in grid units.
 
 Default = 100.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Maximum half-aperture in y direction, in grid units.
Help.Text:
ktmig - GRID_AP_Y_MAX
Maximum half-aperture in y direction, in grid units.
 
 Default = 100.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0

Help.Tip: Spacing within aperture and travel time table.
Help.Text:
ktmig - GRID_AP_X_INC
Spacing within aperture and travel time table.
 
 Default = -1 = 5. * X_INC
 Allowed = real
 For depth imaging this defines the maximum size of travel time tables.
 Increasing this increases memory linearly and CPU nonlinearly.
 The travel time table is computed and saved using a spacing of GRID_AP_X_INC
 between locations within the table. The larger GRID_AP_X_INC gets the less CPU
 time and memory is recquired at the cost of decreased accuracy.

Help.Tip: Y spacing within precomputed tables.
Help.Text:
ktmig - GRID_AP_Y_INC
Y spacing within precomputed tables.
 
 Default = -1 = 5 * Y_INC
 Allowed = real
 kdmig precomputes a number of tables on a coarse horizontal grid.
 GRID_AP_Y_INC defines the Y spacing within these tables.
 Needed values are computed from these tables via linear interpolation.
 Decreasing GRID_AP_Y_INC increases memory linearly and CPU nonlinearly.

Help.Tip: Array of times, in seconds, corresponding to AP_X values.
Help.Text:
ktmig - TIM_AP_X
Array of times, in seconds, corresponding to AP_X values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real  (linked array)
 Array of times, in seconds, corresponding to values of half-aperture in the
 x direction.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DIST_AP_X
Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of time dependent half-aperture values to use in the x direction, in
 feet or meters.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_X.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
Help.Text:
ktmig - GRID_AP_X
Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of time dependent half-aperture values to use in the x direction, in
 grid units.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_X.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
Help.Text:
ktmig - ANG_AP_X
Array of values of half-aperture to use in x direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of time dependent half-aperture values to use in the x direction, in
 degrees.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_X.

Help.Tip: Array of times, in seconds, corresponding to AP_Y values.
Help.Text:
ktmig - TIM_AP_Y
Array of times, in seconds, corresponding to AP_Y values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real (linked array)
 Array of times, in seconds, corresponding to values of half-aperture in the
 y direction.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DIST_AP_Y
Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of time dependent half-aperture values to use in the y direction, in
 feet or meters.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_Y.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
Help.Text:
ktmig - GRID_AP_Y
Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of time dependent half-aperture values to use in the y direction, in
 grid units.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_Y.

Help.Tip: Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
Help.Text:
ktmig - ANG_AP_Y
Array of values of half-aperture to use in y direction.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (linked array)
 Array of time dependent half-aperture values to use in the y direction, in
 degrees.  Actual values used will not exceed AP_MAX_Y.

Help.Tip: Maximum component of offset in the x direction.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OFF_X_MAX
Maximum component of offset in the x direction.
 
 Default = (OFF_TOT-1)*OFF_INC+OFF_INIT+OFF_INC/2
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Maximum component of offset in the x direction, in feet or meters.

Help.Tip: Maximum component of offset in the y direction.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OFF_Y_MAX
Maximum component of offset in the y direction.
 
 Default = (OFF_TOT-1)*OFF_INC+OFF_INIT+OFF_INC/2
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Maximum component of offset in the y direction, in feet or meters.

Help.Tip: Array of values of maximum offset corresponding to OFF_TIM values.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OFFSETS
Array of values of maximum offset corresponding to OFF_TIM values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0 (linked array)
 Array of values of maximum offset, in feet or meters, corresponding to
 OFF_TIM values.  OFF_TIM and OFFSETS constitute a time-offset mute for KTMIG.

Help.Tip: Array of times, in seconds, corresponding to OFFSETS values.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OFF_TIM
Array of times, in seconds, corresponding to OFFSETS values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real (linked array)
 Array of times, in seconds, corresponding to maximum offset values.  OFF_TIM
 and OFFSETS constitute a time-offset mute for KTMIG.

Help.Tip: Whether to use polygon arrays, polygon file or no polygon.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_POLY
Whether to use polygon arrays, polygon file or no polygon.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = NONE
 Allowed = ARRAY_POLY
 Allowed = PATH_POLY
 If OPT_POLY = NONE, then no polygon restriction will be used.
 
 If OPT_POLY = ARRAY_POLY, then define polygons by arrays on GUI (X_POLY,
 Y_POLY and ID_POLY).
 
 If OPT_POLY = PATH_POLY, then define polygons by polygon file whose pathname
 is entered in PATH_POLY.

Help.Tip: Array of x-coordinate polygon vertex values.
Help.Text:
ktmig - X_POLY
Array of x-coordinate polygon vertex values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real (array)
 Array of x-coordinate polygon vertex values linked with Y_POLY and ID_POLY.

Help.Tip: Array of y-coordinate polygon vertex values.
Help.Text:
ktmig - Y_POLY
Array of y-coordinate polygon vertex values.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real (array)
 Array of y-coordinate polygon vertex values linked with X_POLY and ID_POLY.

Help.Tip: Array of polygon identifiers.
Help.Text:
ktmig - ID_POLY
Array of polygon identifiers.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int (array)
 Array of polygon identifiers linked with X_POLY and ID_POLY.  All vertex
 values linked with the same ID_POLY value pertain to the same polygon.
 Different polygons must have different ID_POLY values.  All array entries
 associated with the same polygon must be consecutive.

Help.Tip: polygon path name for immediately loading polygon to gui.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SELECT_PATH_POLY_LOAD
polygon path name for immediately loading polygon to gui.

Help.Tip: Pathname for polygon file to load immediately to gui.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PATH_POLY_LOAD
Pathname for polygon file to load immediately to gui.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = char
 
 Polygon files for this option are ascii files whose first three columns
 carry the same information as X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY, respectively.
 Any columns beyond three are ignored. The third column for ID_POLY is
 optional. If not present, the ID_POLY is set to the value of 1 for all
 vertices. Values is the three columns should be separated by spaces.
 
 If successfully opened and processed the polygon vertex values are
 immediately entered into the X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY arrays on the
 gui. These can then be saved in the work file. The name of the file
 associated with these coordinates is NOT saved in the work file and
 is only read in the gui stage.
 
 Currently, there is a limit of 100 vertices that can be read in this
 manner.
 
 NOTE: parameter OPT_POLY must be set to option ARRAY_POLY to use
       the polygon read in using this option.

Help.Tip: polygon path name.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SELECT_PATH_POLY
polygon path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname for polygon file.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PATH_POLY
Pathname for polygon file.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = char
 Polygon files are ascii files whose first three columns carry the same
 information as X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY respectively and can have an
 optional fourth column carrying header value information.  Only the first
 three columns are used by KTMIG.
 
 The SETPOLY process requires polygon files with four columns.  Files prepared
 for SETPOLY can be used with KTMIG, although the fourth column will be
 ignored.

Help.Tip: Isotropic or type of anisotropic method to use.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_ANISO
Isotropic or type of anisotropic method to use.
 
 Default = ISOTROPIC
 Allowed = ISOTROPIC   (Do not use an anisotropic method.)
 Allowed = ANISOTROPIC (Use vertical transverse isotropic (VTI) method.)

Help.Tip: Whether to write a vleocity trace file.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_VTRC
Whether to write a vleocity trace file.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = NO    Do not write a velocity trace file.
 Allowed = MODEL Write the velocity trace file using the model grid.
 Allowed = IMAGE Write the velocity trace file using the image grid.

Help.Tip: Path name for model coefficient trace file.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PATH_VTRC
Path name for model coefficient trace file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = CHAR

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant or spatially varying velocity.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_VEL
Whether to use constant or spatially varying velocity.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT
 
 If OPT_VEL = CONSTANT, then constant velocity migration will be used,
 using the velocity specified by parameter CONST_VEL_MIG.
 
 If OPT_VEL = PATH, then use spatially varying velocities defined in
 the file whose pathname is entered in PATH_VEL.

Help.Tip: Constant velocity used for imaging (not for angle calculations).
Help.Text:
ktmig - CONST_VEL_MIG
Constant velocity used for imaging (not for angle calculations).
 
 Default = 2000
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 If CONST_VEL_ANG = 0.0, then use PATH_VEL for the migration velocity.

Help.Tip: velocity path name.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SELECT_PATH_VEL
velocity path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname for migration stacking velocity file.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PATH_VEL
Pathname for migration stacking velocity file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 For 3D the velocity file specified by PATHNAME_VEL must use the header words
 specified by HDR_X and HDR_Y as coordinates.  For 2D it must use the header
 word specified by HDR_X as coordinate.

Help.Tip: Whether to use constant or spatialy varying eta.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_ETA
Whether to use constant or spatialy varying eta.
 
 Default = CONSTANT
 Allowed = PATH
 Allowed = CONSTANT
 
 If OPT_ETA = CONSTANT, use constant value for eta, specified in parameter
 CONST_ETA.
 
 If OPT_ETA = PATH, use spatially varying values for eta, defined in a
 file whose path is entered in PATH_ETA.

Help.Tip: Constant eta parameter for transverse isotropic media.
Help.Text:
ktmig - CONST_ETA
Constant eta parameter for transverse isotropic media.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = 1.0 > CONST_ETA >= 0.0
 CONST_ETA is the parameter indicating the (constant) amount of anisotropy in
 transverse isotropic media.  KTMIG modifies the migration operator to be
 consistent with the CONST_ETA value specified.
 
 CONST_ETA = 0.0 indicates a medium that is isotropic and no anisotropic
 correction is made.  CONST_ETA = 0.1 is a typical value for a transverse
 isotropic medium.

Help.Tip: eta path name.
Help.Text:
ktmig - SELECT_PATH_ETA
eta path name.

Help.Tip: Pathname of file containing varying eta information.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PATH_ETA
Pathname of file containing varying eta information.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = char
 PATH_ETA is the pathname of a file containing variable eta information for a
 medium with variable transverse isotropy.  KTMIG modifies the migration
 operator to be consistent with the eta values specified.
 
 The file specified by PATH_ETA is an ordinary CPS velocity file that carries
 eta values rather than velocity values.

Help.Tip: Mute time, in seconds, for near trace.
Help.Text:
ktmig - TIM_NEAR
Mute time, in seconds, for near trace.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real
 TIM_NEAR is used to adjust the migration velocity when doing anisotropic
 migration.  TIM_NEAR is not a mute parameter.

Help.Tip: Mute time, in seconds, for the far offset.
Help.Text:
ktmig - TIM_FAR
Mute time, in seconds, for the far offset.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real
 TIM_FAR is used to adjust the migration velocity when doing anisotropic
 migration.  TIM_FAR is not a mute parameter.

Help.Tip: Far offset, corresponding to TIM_FAR.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OFF_FAR
Far offset, corresponding to TIM_FAR.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real
 OFF_FAR is used to adjust the migration velocity when doing anisotropic
 migration.  OFF_FAR is not a mute parameter.

Help.Tip: Whether migration velocity analysis (FCTR_VEL array) is active.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_VA
Whether migration velocity analysis (FCTR_VEL array) is active.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO
 If OPT_VA = YES, then the FCTR_VEL array is active for migration velocity
 analysis.
 
 If OPT_VA = NO, then the FCTR_VEL array is inactive.

Help.Tip: Array of velocity multipliers for migration velocity analysis.
Help.Text:
ktmig - FCTR_VEL
Array of velocity multipliers for migration velocity analysis.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0  (array)
 KTMIG produces a sequence of velocity fields by multiplying the input
 velocity field (including any anisotropic adjustment) by each of the elements
 of the FCTR_VEL array in turn.  It then uses each of these velocity fields to
 produce an output image.  As many output images are created as the number of
 elements in the FCTR_VEL array.
 
 Output image traces are labeled in header word 24 with the index number of
 the FCTR_VEL array corresponding to that image (from 1 to the total number of
 multipliers) and in header word 63 with the corresponding velocity
 multiplier.

Help.Tip: Eta scale factors.
Help.Text:
ktmig - FCTR_ETA
Eta scale factors.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = real (array) > 0
 Multiple images are constructed for the different imaging velocity scales
 in Velocity .
 The time imaging velocity is the input eta * FCTR_ETA
 The depth imaging travel time is
 the computed time for the input velocity / FCTR_ETA

Help.Tip: Button that displays memory and disk requirements when pressed.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DISPLAY_INFO
Button that displays memory and disk requirements when pressed.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = -
 Pressing the DISPLAY_INFO button causes memory and disk requirements to be
 calculated and displayed.

Help.Tip: Type of image node divison.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DIV_TYPE
Type of image node divison.
 
 Default = ROUND
 Allowed = ROUND for round robin distribution
 Allowed = BLOCK for block distribution
 Allowed = ZERO  to distrubte to pe 0 only.
 Allowed = ALL   to distrubte to all pes.
 
 DIV_TYPE defines the type of Y node division among pes
   0 = round robin, 1 = block, 2 = 0 only, 3 = all
 
   DIV_TYPE=ROUND, Round robin division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes 1,5, 9,..., 97
   pe 1 gets Y nodes 2,6,10,..., 98
   pe 2 gets Y nodes 3,7,11,..., 99
   pe 3 gets Y nodes 4,8,12,...,100
 
   DIV_TYPE=BLOCK, Block division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes  1- 25
   pe 1 gets Y nodes 26- 50
   pe 2 gets Y nodes 51- 75
   pe 3 gets Y nodes 76-100
 
   DIV_TYPE=ZERO, 0 only division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 1 gets Y nodes  0-  0
   pe 2 gets Y nodes  0-  0
   pe 3 gets Y nodes  0-  0
 
   DIV_TYPE=ALL, all division
   means for a job with NY_MIG=100, Number of PES=4
   pe 0 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 1 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 2 gets Y nodes  1-100
   pe 3 gets Y nodes  1-100

Help.Tip: Use ppio for trace io.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_USE_PPIO
Use ppio for trace io.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES use ppio routines.
 Allowed = NO use TRCIO routines.

Help.Tip: What method for interpolating output traces.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_MAP_APPLY
What method for interpolating output traces.
 
 Default = MAP_APPLY_I
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_C Use MAP_APPLY_C   which does not include gradients.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_F Use MAP_APPLY_F   which does not include gradients.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_G Use MAP_APPLY_G   which does     include gradients.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_H Use MAP_APPLY_H   which includes gradients and paz.
 Allowed = MAP_APPLY_I Use MAP_APPLY_H_C which includes gradients and paz.
 KMIG will use MAP_APPLY_C when MIG_TYPE = DMO or OPT_OUTPUT .ne. IMAGE

Help.Tip: Number of cpus per parallel processing group.
Help.Text:
ktmig - CPUS_PER_GROUP
Number of cpus per parallel processing group.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 kdmig will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by kdmig and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: Number of independent groups of parallel processors to use.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PAR_GROUPS
Number of independent groups of parallel processors to use.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = number of  CPUs in job >= int > 0
 KTMIG associates CPUs into PAR_GROUPS independent groups.  Each group will
 receive a different subset of the input traces and will produce an image
 independent of the other groups.  The separate images produced by the groups
 are composited together to form the output image.
 
 Each group should have the same number of CPUs (the number of CPUs in the job
 should be a multiple of PAR_GROUPS).
 
 If PAR_GROUPS = 1, then all CPUs contribute to a single common image.
 
 If PAR_GROUPS = number of CPUs, then each CPU produces an image independent
 of the other CPUs and these separate images are composited to
 form the output.
 
 Generally you should set PAR_GROUPS to the largest value that permits the
 image subset for each CPU to fit in memory.

Help.Tip: Total number of cpus in job.
Help.Text:
ktmig - NUM_CPUS
Total number of cpus in job.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = 1 <= int <= number pes in job
 kdmig will break the NUM_CPUS = number of pes in the job, processors
 into PAR_GROUPS groups of processors.
 Each group will have a maximum of CPUS_PER_GROUP proecessors in the job,
 and will image a subset of the input traces and construct
 an image indiependantly from th eother groups.  At the end
 of processing the separate images will be summed to gether
 by kdmig and the result output on all pes.
 It is strongly reccommended that you set the number of
 processors, NUM_CPUS, in a job be a multiple of CPUS_PER_GROUP,
 so each group will have the same number of processors.  It is
 also best that all processors in a job be the same speed.
 
 The maximum number of processors in any group is :
 m_pe_grp = ( NUM_CPUS + par_groups - 1 ) / par_groups
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_2 = par_groups * m_pe_grp - NUM_CPUS
 The number of groups which use m_pe_grp - 1 processors is :
 n_pe_grp_1 = NUM_CPUS - n_pe_grp_2

Help.Tip: What level of map print.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_MAP_PRINT
What level of map print.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = int>= 0
 Higher values of OPT_MAP_PRINT print the map values at more stages
 in the computation.
 opt_map_print .eq. -1 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 1 after ksum_map_compute.
 opt_map_print .eq. -2 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 2 after ksum_map_gradient.
 opt_map_print .eq. -3 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 3 after ksum_paz_interpolate.
 opt_map_print .eq. -4 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 4 after ksum_mute_turn.
 opt_map_print .eq. -5 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 5 after ksum_doppler_apply.
 opt_map_print .eq. -6 .or. opt_map_print .ge. 6 after ksum_map_apply.
 Maps for x,y image node locations FIRST_MAP_PRINT to LAST_MAP_PRINT
 are printed.

Help.Tip: First x,y imag enode to print map for.
Help.Text:
ktmig - FIRST_MAP_PRINT
First x,y imag enode to print map for.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int>= 0
 Maps for x,y image node locations FIRST_MAP_PRINT to LAST_MAP_PRINT
 are printed.

Help.Tip: Last x,y imag enode to print map for.
Help.Text:
ktmig - LAST_MAP_PRINT
Last x,y imag enode to print map for.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int>= 0
 Maps for x,y image node locations FIRST_MAP_PRINT to LAST_MAP_PRINT
 are printed.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of anti-alias filters to use.
Help.Text:
ktmig - NUM_AA
Maximum number of anti-alias filters to use.
 
 Default = 31
 Allowed = int > 0
 KTMIG uses the Claerbout integration method for anti-aliasing which makes a
 number of copies of the input trace, each with a different anti-alias filter
 applied.
 
 NUM_AA = 31 is usually sufficient, NUM_AA = 40 is probably excessive.

Help.Tip: Effective output trace physical spacing, in feet or meters.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DIST_AA
Effective output trace physical spacing, in feet or meters.
 
 Default = compute default from transformation grid
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 The effective output trace physical spacing, in feet or meters, for use in
 calculating the anti-alias filter.  It should be roughly the average of
 the inline and the crossline physical spacing of output traces.  Larger
 distances produce more severe anti-aliasing, so using the larger of the
 inline or the crossline output trace physical spacing is the most
 conservative approach.

Help.Tip: Antialias normalization.
Help.Text:
ktmig - NORM_AA
Antialias normalization.
 
 Default = MAX_AMP
 Allowed = MAX_AMP Preserve maximum ampplitude.
 Allowed = NONE    No antialias nrmaliazation.

Help.Tip: Type of amplitude treatment.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_AMPLITUDE
Type of amplitude treatment.
 
 Default = HPHILLIPS
 Allowed = HPHILLIPS
 Allowed = HCONOCO
 Allowed = USER
 To get the heritage Conoco   ampltiude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = HCONOCO
 To get the heritage Phillips ampltiude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = HPHILLIPS
 To get some other            amplitude scaling use OPT_AMPLITUDE = USER
 OPT_AMPLITUDE  = HCONOCO sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = HCONOCO,   PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +0., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -0.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE  = HPHILLIPS sets
 OPT_AMP_COSINE = HPHILLIPS, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = +1., PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = -1.
 OPT_AMPLITUDE  = USER allows an arbitray combination of parameters.
 OPT_AMP_COSINE, PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP, PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
 The v(t) amplitude scaling computes a v(t) curved ray amplitude correction
 This assumes no divergence correction has been applied to the input data
 prior to input to imaging.
 Heritage Conoco's ampltiude scaling was cos(dip)
 this assumes a divergence correction has been applied to the input data
 prior to input to imaging and zero offset.
 Heritage Philip's ampltiude scaling was
 ( time / depth ) * cos(source)**2+cos(reciever)**2)
 this assumes no divergence correction has been applied to the input data
 prior to input to imaging.

Help.Tip: Type of cosine dip samplitude scaling.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_AMP_COSINE
Type of cosine dip samplitude scaling.
 
 Default = HCONOCO
 Allowed = HCONOCO
 Allowed = HPHILLIPS

Help.Tip: Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP
Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (TIME - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP
 to each input trace before imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = 0. yields no amplitude scaling before imaging.

Help.Tip: Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
Help.Text:
ktmig - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP
Scale input data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (TIME - MIN_AMP_SCALE_INP) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP
 to each input trace before imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_INP = 0. yields no amplitude scaling before imaging.

Help.Tip: Scale output data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
Scale output data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (TIME - MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
 to each output trace after imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = 0. yields no amplitude scaling after imaging.
 For time migration TIME will be output time.

Help.Tip: Scale output data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
Help.Text:
ktmig - MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT
Scale output data by (TIME-MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT)**PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT.
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = real
 Apply an amplitude scaling of (TIME - MIN_AMP_SCALE_OUT) ** PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT
 to each output trace after imaging.
 Using PWR_AMP_SCALE_OUT = 0. yields no amplitude scaling after imaging.
 For time migration TIME will be output time.

Help.Tip: Power for (frequency ** PWR_FILT) filter applied to input.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PWR_FILT
Power for (frequency ** PWR_FILT) filter applied to input.
 
 Default = 0.5 for 2D, 1.0 for 3D
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 Theoretical values are PWR_FILT = 0.5 for 2D migration and PWR_FILT = 1.0 for
 3D migration.  (But migrating a single line from a 3D survey to a single
 output line is really 2D so in that case PWR_FILT should be 0.5.)
 
 Lower values of PWR_FILT emphasize low frequencies, higher values of PWR_FILT
 emphasize high frequencies.  Adjusting the PWR_FILT value allows you to
 adjust the image frequency balance and the apparent amount of noise in the
 image.  This may be desirable for some datasets.

Help.Tip: Phase shift, in degrees, to apply to the input traces.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PHASE_FILT
Phase shift, in degrees, to apply to the input traces.
 
 Default = 45 for 2D, 90 for 3D
 Allowed = 45 or 90
 Theoretically correct values are PHASE_FILT = 45 for 2D migration and
 PHASE_FILT = 90 for 3D migration.  (But migrating a single line from a 3D
 survey to a single output line is really 2D so in that case PHASE_FILT should
 be 45.)

Help.Tip: Number of input traces between migration status prints.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PRINT_INC
Number of input traces between migration status prints.
 
 Default = 1000
 Allowed = int > 0
 KTMIG writes informational text on CPU time and elapsed time and location of
 input and output traces for the first few input traces and again after every
 additional PRINT_INC input traces.
 
 PRINT_INC = 0 disables migration status prints.

Help.Tip: Whether memory allocation details will be printed in .rpt file?
Help.Text:
ktmig - PRINT_MEMORY
Whether memory allocation details will be printed in .rpt file?
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES/NO

Help.Tip: Print debug information.
Help.Text:
ktmig - PRINT_DEBUG
Print debug information.
 
 Default = BRIEF
 Allowed = NONE     - no debug information is printed.
 Allowed = BRIEF    - default debug information is printed.
 Allowed = DETAILED - detailed debug information is printed.
 Allowed = DEBUG    - full debug information is printed.

Help.Tip: Whether stack scaling is used.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_FOS_SCALE
Whether stack scaling is used.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO
 If OPT_FOS_SCALE = YES, then stack scaling is used.
 
 If OPT_FOS_SCALE = NO, then stack scaling is not used and fold of stack
 sampling
 is disabled.

Help.Tip: Fold of Stack Exponential for stack scaling.
Help.Text:
ktmig - FOS_PWR
Fold of Stack Exponential for stack scaling.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = 1.0 >= FOS_PWR >= 0.0
 Perform stack scaling of output trace sample values by dividing the
 composited trace sample value by the local fold raised to the FOS_PWR power.

Help.Tip: First time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
Help.Text:
ktmig - FOS_TIM_INIT
First time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
 
 Default = TSTRT
 Allowed = real >= TSTRT

Help.Tip: Increment between times to sample fold of stack, in seconds.
Help.Text:
ktmig - FOS_TIM_INC
Increment between times to sample fold of stack, in seconds.
 
 Default = DT
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Last time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
Help.Text:
ktmig - FOS_TIM_LAST
Last time for sampling fold of stack, in seconds.
 
 Default = end of trace
 Allowed = real >= FOS_TIM_INIT

Help.Tip: Number of times for sampling fold of stack.
Help.Text:
ktmig - FOS_TIM_TOT
Number of times for sampling fold of stack.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = int > 0

Help.Tip: Whether a stretch mute (Doppler mute) is used.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_DOPP
Whether a stretch mute (Doppler mute) is used.
 
 Default = YES
 Allowed = YES/NO
 If OPT_DOPP = YES, then use a stretch mute.
 
 If OPT_DOPP = NO, then do not use a stretch mute.

Help.Tip: Doppler mute (stretch mute) parameter.
Help.Text:
ktmig - DOPPLER
Doppler mute (stretch mute) parameter.
 
 Default = 3.0
 Allowed = real > 1.0
 In general, the imaging operation causes a short time interval on the input
 trace to occupy a larger time interval on the image trace.  DOPPLER is the
 maximum time stretch factor allowed by the stretch mute.  Portions of the
 migration operator that would produce a time stretch factor greater than
 DOPPLER are muted off.
 
 Larger values of DOPPLER correspond to less severe muting.  Very large values
 may introduce low frequency artifacts.
 
 Smaller values of DOPPLER may eliminate steep dips.

Help.Tip: Mute events whose input time decreases with output time or depth.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OPT_MUTE_TURN
Mute events whose input time decreases with output time or depth.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES, NO
 If OPT_MUTE_TURN = NO,  then allow any input time to output relation ship.
 If OPT_MUTE_TURN = YES, then mute when input time decreases
                         with output time or depth.

Help.Tip: Kirchhoff summation taper length, in seconds.
Help.Text:
ktmig - TIM_TAPER
Kirchhoff summation taper length, in seconds.
 
 Default = 15 * output dt
 Allowed = real > 0.0

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
ktmig - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
Help.Text:
ktmig - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
Help.Text:
ktmig - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------- C P S P R O C E S S
Name : KTMIG (Kirchhoff Time MIGration) Category : migrations Written : 2001-09-14 by: Stephen Chiu Revised : 2006-08-29 by: D. Glover Maturity : production Purpose : 2D and 3D Kirchhoff time migration. Portability: No known limitations. Parallel : YES
------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GENERAL DESCRIPTION
KTMIG is a general 2D or 3D Kirchhoff time migration process that will operate in either the migrate or the model direction.
Coordinates
HDR_X and HDR_Y define the midpoint header words used as coordinates for input traces and the OUTPUT image volume. Allowed values for HDR_X and HDR_Y are (7,8); (8,7); (17,18) or (18,17) only. KTMIG always determines the offset of input traces from header word 6.
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 7,8 or 8,7 (grid coordinates), then KTMIG uses input trace header words 7 and 8 for midpoint and 33, 34, 35 and 36 for azimuth. Header words 17 and 18 for output traces are calculated using the CPS grid transform.
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 17,18 or 18,17 (surveyed coordinates), then KTMIG uses input trace header words 17 and 18 for midpoint and 11, 12, 14 and 15 for azimuth. Header words 7 and 8 for output traces are calculated using the CPS grid transform.
Coordinates of the stacking velocity file specified by PATH_VEL must be identical to header words HDR_X and HDR_Y for 3D and to HDR_X for 2D.
Default Output Image Volume
Trace midpoint locations in the default OUTPUT image volume are specified by the parameters HDR_X, X_INIT, X_INC, X_LAST, X_TOT and similar parameters for the y-coordinate. Additional parameters specify the time and offset dimensions of the default output image volume.
Input trace midpoints need not agree exactly with trace locations defined by the default output image volume.
The output image volume defined by the x-coordinate, y-coordinate, time and offset parameters is the DEFAULT output image volume. Depending on the values assigned to the ALL_OUT, POLYGON and SPARSE parameters and input trace offset values, the traces actually output may be a subset of the default output image volume.
Output Images and Offset Bins
The parameters OFF_INIT, OFF_INC, OFF_LAST and OFF_TOT define a set of offset bins.
If ONE_IMAGE = NO, then:
1. Each KTMIG output image is associated with an offset bin. Header word 6 for output traces is set to the associated offset bin center value.
2. KTMIG migrates each offset bin separately, that is, only input traces with header word 6 within a particular offset bin contribute to the output image associated with that offset bin.
3. The current image is output and a new one started whenever the input trace stream changes to a different offset bin.
4. Output images are produced only for those offset bins that are occupied by input traces.
5. Input traces with offset outside the range of the offset bins are ignored.
If ONE_IMAGE = YES, then:
1. Only a single image is produced regardless of input trace offset.
2. Header word 6 for output traces is set to the center value of the offset bin associated with the offset of the first input trace. The imaging aperture is determined by this same offset bin.
ONE_IMAGE = YES should only be used if virtually all input traces have offset that lies within the offset bin associated with the first input trace.
Aperture Specification
The AP_MAX_X and AP_MAX_Y parameters specify the size of a rectangular aperture, centered on the input trace midpoint. No imaging will occur beyond this aperture regardless of other parameter values.
Additionally a time dependent elliptical aperture is defined in the horizontal plane with foci at the source and receiver locations. The semi-major axis (parallel to the source-receiver direction) is given by offset/2 + AP_X(time), where AP_X is time dependent. The semi-minor axis (perpendicular to the source-receiver direction) is given by AP_Y(time), where AP_Y is time dependent.
In any azimuthal direction from the input trace mid-point, no imaging will occur outside the closer of either the rectangular or the elliptical aperture.
Three sets of aperture parameters are available, allowing you to specify aperture in distance (feet or meters), grid units (units of header words 7 and 8) or angle in degrees.
Anisotropic Migration
KTMIG can perform transverse isotropic migration. Eta can be specified by either CONST_ETA (constant) or PATH_ETA (file containing variable eta values). The parameters TIM_NEAR, TIM_FAR and OFF_FAR specify a pseudo-mute that defines the onset of noticable anisotropy within a CMP. The anisotropic migration algorithm should not significantly affect the moveout of events at offsets within the pseudo-mute.
Offset Mute
The OFFSETS and OFF_TIM linked arrays constitute a time-offset mute for KTMIG. This mute determines the offset of input traces that may contribute to image traces at a given time. This constraint is in addition to the restriction imposed by the aperture parameters.
The time-offset mute can help eliminate artifacts caused by non-physical mapping. A stronger mute will reduce run-time.
Filter
KTMIG applies a filter to the input traces to correct for the effect of the Kirchhoff sum. This filter has a (frequency ** PWR_FILT) component and a phase rotation component. Theoretical values of PWR_FILT are 0.5 for 2D and 1.0 for 3D. Theoretical values of PHASE_FILT are 45 degrees for 2D and 90 degrees for 3D. Lower values of PWR_FILT emphasize low frequencies, higher values of PWR_FILT emphasize high frequencies. Adjusting the PWR_FILT value allows you to adjust the image frequency balance and the apparent amount of noise in the image. This may be desirable for some datasets.
Amplitude Balance and Stack Scaling
Because aperture usually increases with trace time, an output trace usually receives contributions from fewer input traces shallow and from more traces deep. This may cause an amplitude imbalance on output traces. A fold of stack scaling can be applied to compensate for this imbalance. Fold of stack scaling divides the composited output trace sample value by the local fold raised to a power.
Normally fold of stack scaling is disabled in KTMIG and any output amplitude imbalance is corrected using a process such as MVXP, DBGAIN, TPOW or EXO.
Diagnostic Output
KTMIG can produce diagnostic outputs of velocity, two-way travel time, amplitude factor or anti-alias coefficient if the appropriate option is selected in OPT_OUTPUT. When producing diagnostic outputs, a single trace should be input and ALL_OUT set to YES. Output trace samples will be dead outside the specified aperture.
For normal imaging operation, set OPT_OUTPUT to IMAGE.
Polygons
The polygon parameters allow you to define one or more closed polygons on the x-y image plane. If one or more polygons are defined, then imaging is performed only to traces within the polygons or on a polygon boundary. All traces in the coordinate volume will be output, but those outside the polygons will be dead.
Polygons can be specified with the X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY linked array parameters. X and Y coordinates for a vertex are specified by X_POLY and Y_POLY.
1. All vertices for a single polygon must be entered sequentially (clockwise or counterclockwise).
2. All vertices for a single polygon must be in consecutive rows.
3. All vertices for a single polygon must have the same value of ID_POLY.
4. Different polygons must have different values of ID_POLY (starting with 1 and incrementing by 1).
Alternatively, polygons can be specified by a polygon file. Polygon files are ascii files whose first three columns carry the same information as X_POLY, Y_POLY and ID_POLY respectively and can have an optional fourth column carrying header value information. Only the first three columns are used by KTMIG.
The SETPOLY process requires polygon files with four columns. Files prepared for SETPOLY can be used with KTMIG, although the fourth column will be ignored.
Sparse Output
It is often desirable to output a few lines or scattered CMPs rather than the entire default image volume. The sparse output option allows you to define one or more distinct grids of output traces where each such grid is a subset of the default image volume.
The first row of the SP_X parameter linked arrays defines a set of HDR_X values and the first row of the SP_Y parameter linked arrays defines a set of HDR_Y values. This row defines a grid of output traces whose midpoints have the HDR_X and HDR_Y values in common. (Output trace midpoints are the intersection of the HDR_X and HDR_Y values specified in the first row.)
Each additional row of the SP_X and SP_Y parameter linked arrays defines a separate grid of output trace locations.
The sparse output volume is the union of all of the grids defined by the entries in the SP_X and SP_Y parameter linked arrays.
HDR_X and HDR_Y values specified by the sparse output parameters must agree exactly with trace locations defined by the default output image volume.
Parallelization
KTMIG associates CPUs into PAR_GROUPS number of independent CPU groups.
1. The input dataset is partitioned into PAR_GROUPS distinct subsets, with each group receiving one subset of the input dataset.
2. All CPUs within a group receive the same input traces.
3. Each group has its own entire image volume that is separate from the image volumes associated with other groups.
4. The image volume for each group is partitioned into subsets with one subset for each CPU. Each CPU will image only to the image subset with which it is associated.
Each group should have the same number of CPUs (the number of CPUs in the job should be a multiple of PAR_GROUPS).
If PAR_GROUPS = 1, then all CPUs contribute to a single common image.
If PAR_GROUPS = number of CPUs, then each CPU produces an image independent of the other CPUs and these separate images are composited by KTMIG to form the output.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ADVICE FOR USERS
General
HDR_X and HDR_Y will normally be 7,8 (or 8,7).
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 7,8 (or 8,7), then header words 7, 8, 33, 34, 35 and 36 on input traces must NOT be integerized (rounded).
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 17,18 (or 18,17), then header words 17, 18, 11, 12, 14 and 15 on input traces must NOT be integerized (rounded).
The CPS grid transform must be set properly in CFE.
Coordinates of the stacking velocity file specified by PATH_VEL must be identical to header words HDR_X and HDR_Y for 3D and to HDR_X for 2D.
All CPUs in a parallel job should have the same speed.
2D vs. 3D
If DIMENSION = 2D, then a 2D algorithm is used, all "X" parameters pertain to the inline direction, all "Y" parameters are ignored and the aperture has extent in the inline direction only. Only one 2D line can be migrated at once.
If DIMENSION = 3D, then a 3D algorithm is used and both "X" parameters and "Y" parameters are active.
PWR_FILT and PHASE_FILT have different default values for 2D and for 3D; be sure to set them properly.
Input Trace Offset and Sort Order
Input data should always be sorted to common offsets.
For 3D before-stack work: Usually one offset at a time is migrated and ONE_IMAGE is set to YES so that input traces with offset values at a bin edge do not trigger a new image.
For 2D before-stack work: Usually ONE_IMAGE is set to NO and the entire line is migrated at once. In this case input traces occupying a new offset bin will trigger the start of a new image.
Output Trace Sort Order
Sort order of output traces from fastest to slowest:
If SORT_ORDER = X_IS FAST: HDR_X, HDR_Y, offset bin as occupied and index of FCTR_VEL array.
If SORT_ORDER = Y_IS FAST: HDR_Y, HDR_X, offset bin as occupied and index of FCTR_VEL array.
It may be necessary to sort output traces to the desired order.
Before Stack vs. After Stack Migration
For after stack (zero-offset) migration using KTMIG the offset header word of input traces should be set to zero and you should set ONE_IMAGE = YES, OFF_TOT = 1 and OFF_INIT = 0.0. For before stack migration, the offset parameters should be set to define the desired offset bins. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- REVISION HISTORY

------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ADVICE FOR USERS
General
HDR_X and HDR_Y will normally be 7,8 (or 8,7).
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 7,8 (or 8,7), then header words 7, 8, 33, 34, 35 and 36 on input traces must NOT be integerized (rounded).
If HDR_X and HDR_Y = 17,18 (or 18,17), then header words 17, 18, 11, 12, 14 and 15 on input traces must NOT be integerized (rounded).
The CPS grid transform must be set properly in CFE.
Coordinates of the stacking velocity file specified by PATH_VEL must be identical to header words HDR_X and HDR_Y for 3D and to HDR_X for 2D.
All CPUs in a parallel job should have the same speed.
2D vs. 3D
If DIMENSION = 3D, then a 3D algorithm is used and both "X" parameters and "Y" parameters are active. The migration velocity file must be 3D.
If DIMENSION = 2D, then a 2D algorithm is used, all "X" parameters pertain to the inline direction, all "Y" parameters are ignored and the aperture has extent in the inline direction only. Only one 2D line can be migrated in each job. The migration velocity file may be 2D or 3D.
If DIMENSION = MULT_2D, then a 2D algorithm is used, all "X" parameters pertain to the inline direction and the aperture has extent in the inline direction only. HOWEVER the "Y" parameters must be set appropriately for the HDR_Y values in the separate 2D lines. Several 2D lines can be migrated in one job. The migration velocity file must be 3D.
PWR_FILT and PHASE_FILT have different default values for 2D and for 3D; be sure to set them properly.
Input Trace Offset and Sort Order
Input data should always be sorted to common offsets.
For 3D before-stack work: Usually one offset at a time is migrated and ONE_IMAGE is set to YES so that input traces with offset values at a bin edge do not trigger a new image.
For 2D before-stack work: Usually ONE_IMAGE is set to NO and the entire line is migrated at once. In this case input traces occupying a new offset bin will trigger the start of a new image.
Output Trace Sort Order
Sort order of output traces from fastest to slowest:
If SORT_ORDER = X_IS FAST: Index of FCTR_VEL array, HDR_X, HDR_Y, offset bin as occupied.
If SORT_ORDER = Y_IS FAST: Index of FCTR_VEL array, HDR_Y, HDR_X, offset bin as occupied.
It may be necessary to sort output traces to the desired order.
Before Stack vs. After Stack Migration
For after stack (zero-offset) migration using KTMIG the offset header word of input traces should be set to zero and you should set ONE_IMAGE = YES, OFF_TOT = 1 and OFF_INIT = 0.0. For before stack migration, the offset parameters should be set to define the desired offset bins. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------
